title: Getting Started
content:
Getting Started # This page is meant to get you acquinted with Bert
Available Features # Bert comes with a wide array of features such as:
Booking Time in the Beta Lab Completing Trainings Checking Tool Availability …and much more! For a full list, select the Features tab in the menu.
Logging In # When you first open Bert, you will be redirected to a Google Oauth2 Login Page
Select your Berkeley Carroll (@berkeleycarroll.org) Account
IMPORTANT: Do not select another email (such as your personal). This will block you from being to access Bert.
Bert will now ask for permission to access various elements of your Google Account (such as Calendar, Classroom, etc.). Select allow. Navigating Bert # Bert can be explored using the Navigation Bar at the top of the screen.
At any time, you can select the Bert Logo at the top left of the screen to be returned to the Home Page.
Logging Out # If you wish to sign out of Bert:
Select the dropdown menu with your name and press Sign Out. On the screen that appears, confirm you wish to sign out by pressing Yes, Sign Out

title: Booking the Lab
content:
Booking the Lab # Learn how to reserve space in the Beta Lab.
IMPORTANT: If you plan to reserve tools, materials or storage you must reserve through Bert.
Book Through Google Calendar # There are three distinct Google Calendars for each area of the lab:
Classroom Area Power Tool Area Machine Shop Clicking the links above will add them to your Google Calendar where you can view their upcoming and past events.
To reserve the lab, you can then invite any (or all) of these calendars as an attendee.
Reserve Through Bert # You can also book the lab through Bert itself.

title: FAQ
content:
FAQ - Frequently Asked Questions # What is Bert? # Bert (or the Beta Lab Resource Tool) is a site devoted to helping Berkeley Carroll teachers and students leverage tools, materials and space available in the Beta Lab.
What is the Beta Lab? # The Berkeley Carroll Beta Lab is a 2000 square foot, two-level STEAM lab, providing the space, equipment and expertise for Middle and Upper School teachers and students to meaningfully explore the connections between science, technology, engineering, art and math through complex labs and student-directed projects.
Think about like a library, but instead of books: we have tools!
